title: What did the Germans think of the Italians during WW2? - Quora

response.answer_text: We were an ally who was worse than an enemy and the Germans rightly remarked it. Like many other Italians I think that Mussolini was a British agent who dragged Italy into that war with the purpose of causing trouble to the Germans. Mussolini was the only one who wanted Italy to take part in WWII against the opinion of all government. Mussolini waged war against Greece dragging the Germans in a war against Yugoslavia that absorbed important Wehrmacht resources badly needed otherwhere. Mussolini blocked the development of Italian heavy tanks (FIAT 2000): only 12 tons tanks were allowed in a war of 30 tons tanks or heavier (see Mussolini’s biography by Luigi BARZINI junior). Heavy tanks were a weapon of vital importance for a country like Italy poor of raw materials and fuels and confronted by hordes of enemy tanks. Mussolini decided (against the opinion of all photographic experts) that British battleships “Valiant” and “Queen Elizabeth” were not sunk by Italian frogmen in the port of Alexandria as they were: he forbade our fleet from supplying Rommel who became a lamed duck at EL Alamein. According to documents published by “The Guardian” and well before “The Guardian” by the Italian newspaper “Il Borghese” in the sixties, Mussolini was paid by the “Entente secret services” to found his newspaper “Il Popolo d’Italia” and use it to drag Italy into WWI on the side of France and Britain. He was on the payroll of MI5. According to recent “discoveries” made in Italy Mussolini was killed by British officer Robert MACCARONE to prevent him from speaking. Still a mystery is why the Allied didn’t jail Mussolini after Italy’s surrender and never prosecuted the war criminals they put at his place: a mystery that could be explained by the fact that also BADOGLIO, CAVIGLIA and company worked in reality for the British as some documents seem to proof. As a conclusion the Germans were right to see Italy as a bunch of traitors and only the Madman who led them could see us as an ally.
